0683EC0FF7674D52B4405E296A6E45D4.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

ECD4FE0BD3E54A169B69AD1E504C73C3.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

497B08568B9D4ECF92FA3CEDED21C92C.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

554DB37BC1814CECA2416A1EA8B0551A.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

E833759609B142D4851037AB5D1B074E.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

C49E6997BD154E0A89D8C44A7539B40A.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

EB7C9D02686B4540BE5AE6C98E76976C.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

0A708812132A4DA5BD62B9C3292BADF7.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

776A865EDF4B40CFA1296F3AF6A6D90A.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

7CA6EB18A0A74C53A10FF506E26B4165.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

E876EB106A264763847911159D7942BF.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

0D7DA556249B4B9DBD531F8179A77CEB.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

4B2CEA222D364F5896C7B81C3B29F724.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions

FB3FFA1101494C649753A3E63CF4E412.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours? Who is my supervisor? What should I wear? When will I be provided with safety training? What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement? Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance? What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

5F55E11AC8CD42768ECEB58EE777B3DC.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

E56851F35F3C4E1A9F77044F103F4093.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

FDE30544790C48399012ED93E536C836.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

ACDA12A2C1494B15B6E30B5BC5A53FAD.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

5BC8F1C754A548F28E89A430FF3FD77E.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

57F91A0870D74A46AF4BEACFB1417B83.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

741DE8C8520B480A90A05115E39098EB.description: Explain how precision technology is used to enhance or improve livestock production such as radio frequency identification, biometric sensors and animal management.

4C122B74AE5D4521A83B671B4BD7449D.description: Investigate how aerial and/or satellite imagery is used in managing pasture vegetation and the security and surveillance of livestock and property.

DF2A4AF98FE648D6B0CE3BB3F3D30ECD.description: Explore the impact of machine learning on the precision of livestock equipment.

8D3DD65A50D940FDB167B11A7DBF8800.description: Discuss how precision agriculture technologies impact gathering, storing and interpreting livestock records and data.

2A0CCBAC1C7B4AA4B15ADA154901DBBF.description: Investigate the benefits and application of precision technology in livestock production.

9C23D5DB2C3A46FEAF80087EF4951F13.description: Precision Agriculture – Benefits and Application for Livestock (Optional)

4568D7E838FA4596A12651D4663637C9.description: Explain why fewer medical procedures (e.g., tail docking and beak trimming) are used in organic operations than in conventional operations.

75CE04792308492E856B49625477A251.description: Research alternative treatments (e.g., herbal remedies, Brewer’s yeast, probiotics and activated charcoal) for sick animals.

AC0F1EB5DA914781A42E928B76CEB3E1.description: Examine the necessity of withdrawal periods when medical treatment is unavoidable.

2B7EB332A9E847FCBC1E10739D89C8A6.description: Discuss the exceptions (e.g., antibiotics, hormones and parasiticides) for treatment of livestock with medications.

98F23224A3B74F7DA318B9A265BFE71C.description: Explain why allopathic veterinary drugs are not used in organic livestock operations.

7251F2B220C74FD3A2BFBF8BDB816170.description: Describe how diseases can be mitigated (e.g., buying healthy animals) on organic farms.

EE00DD74D59A4841A0593362C1E0A1B4.description: Explore the diseases, medication and treatment of livestock in an organic operation.

A1F73A9C47F24997A994D9CF6DF58A5C.description: Demonstrate the use of specialized equipment (e.g., honey extractor, tractor attachments and egg sorting machine) designed for a specific task

793B76C41EB5441D882812C151CB5FBE.description: Explain how common types of equipment can be adapted to perform tasks for specialized livestock.

C72FF88183BD4FDAAC372A77AB142F74.description: Explore the technology and equipment used for a specific specialized livestock.

DD10A5271B0349FEA8D0C1E945F5290C.description: Identify associations that support specialized livestock producers.

6538214AD2984E48B9600EAD5FE9ECEB.description: Investigate specialized livestock regulations (e.g., ownership, animal care and export standards).

02A148CD7FD749C187C9FD305FA076B6.description: Explore the benefits and challenges (e.g., market value, disease, marketing of meat, nutritional requirements and facilities) associated with specialized livestock production.

64CCF84DBABD4585B04E54B61B732C0B.description: Identify specialized livestock (e.g., bison, wild boar, bees, egg laying chickens and reindeer) in Saskatchewan.

DD0BF3B94B0D456E8A684EACD527B237.description: Explore how to test for pregnancy and egg fertility of different livestock species.

665966FD55984505BB6085A26B127EFF.description: Compare the different types of breeding technologies such as pasture breeding, hand breeding, artificial insemination, transporting cool semen and embryo transfer

81F4C24A3D164A98A98BFC04F8DFC9E6.description: Explain the operation of common aids (e.g., mount detectors and paints) for heat detection in females.

57756929BA99486799CB9D42DC47FD5E.description: Identify the behaviours and characteristics (e.g., behaviours, eating, socializing and physiological signs of oestrous) exhibited by a female animal when in heat.

2A72BD5746434FD5B4DD1EF224AB216F.description: Explore the reproductive anatomy and terminology for male and female of livestock species (e.g., bull/cow, rooster/hen and stallion/mare).

3B08F658CADF483BB4351F7DEED91456.description: Describe the methods for controlling animal breeding (e.g., castration and separation of males from females).

220AE891402F495690EF10B008452B08.description: Explain the rationale and process of a breeding program.

969DBF5E7BF24920AFC793A4934C9288.description: Organize information into a graph or chart.

D359FBE859FC40E9AFE566CCE53FD6E6.description: Collect pertinent information into a list or table.

276145112D3A44D0A67F24BD9EBFE80A.description: Determine possible data to record for a specific livestock operation in the following categories: breed progeny; • reproduction (e.g., female productivity and male fertility, breeding dates, birthing rates, birth weights and parent/offspring pairings); raising livestock (e.g., farrowing records, weaning weight and rate of gain and age of livestock in different pens); nutrition (e.g., kind of feed, feed rations and days on pasture); animal management (e.g., sick or injured animals, medication records and daily checks); financial management (e.g., inventory, markets, customers, prices, sales, shipments and purchases); and, risk management (e.g., retention of cattle and types of insurance).

2D10C7D57E774697BF4E716EF23AC88F.description: Livestock Record Keeping – Data Collection and Organization (Optional)

48FF6C57C143412593F783623914A4C1.description: Investigate the effect of climate changes (e.g., drought, deluge and storms) on pasture vegetation and land.

FAFBD4D451D84BD0B13F6CB50C4CF789.description: Explain how to calculate animal equivalents to determine the required pastureland for different livestock species.

3971E7EEC60344D5985B3F5E69A83507.description: Describe the characteristics of a pasture that has been over grazed.

2CA72028F3EB40E0933CCD02A7D8D242.description: Describe common livestock concerns to look for when conducting pasture checks, including: missing or stray animals; abnormal animal behaviour; signs of respiratory conditions; eye and skin irregularities; eating disorders and changes to urine and feces; and, signs of dehydration and fever.

B248EECFDAF44C7AA4E09B47635AE778.description: Explain the importance of pen and pasture checks.

44518CEB7AC5458492D77CEAB6099E97.description: Identify personal protective equipment required when mending fences.

A3FF8C98DAB14A7B8A0D4BE342F94780.description: Demonstrate how to use mending tools (e.g., pliers, hammer and posthole digger) to repair fences and corrals.

B889060C52BC46CF8EEC1553896B1C8A.description: Investigate pasture maintenance and livestock checks.

245E3594CA0348768A7DFA9D24C96E27.description: Identify the causes and treatment of gastro-intestinal conditions (e.g., consuming foreign objects, bloat and constipation).

7C0A21034659440F8457E058D5CCAF62.description: Explore the identification and management of genetic deformations (e.g., mule foot, cleft pallet and beak deformity) in livestock.

BCBDB3A2729447A19A3330B43BD86476.description: Identify common symptoms, nature and the precautionary measures to prevent a chosen disease.

C978464699F24C63BB36109F0FDE3A7C.description: Research common conditions such as influenza (e.g., bird and swine flu), African Swine Fever and food-borne illnesses (e.g., Escherichia coli and Salmonella).

1F7A300136B04E7FB6503A5D7B040A0C.description: Investigate the cause, treatment and prevention of injuries (e.g., sprained joints and impaled objects) and open wounds.

DEE4B573F9F04AD59221F215D14E8E04.description: Identify the contents of a basic first aid kit and the general equipment (e.g., pails, stomach tubes and blankets) used to treat injured animals.

49729D3E4A0F4856A59D4A3EBADEC9C0.description: Describe mitigation strategies to prevent new livestock from introducing diseases to a farm.

4BF1B0724135435CAD8DF5737BD90380.description: Explain the importance of biosecurity in ensuring herd health and production.

C35D1A8FF57141D7880D771BDE905B3F.description: Explore the cause, treatment, management and prevention of livestock injuries, conditions and diseases.

15A62E7DBFEF44528737D94094B4F4FE.description: Livestock Health Care – Injuries, Conditions and Diseases (Core)

D80E0AB623464F469055817FA4B7C841.description: Investigate the environmental and safety issues associated with waste disposal.

EC368C5B17834A94A050F0E345EC3CAB.description: Research various waste management systems (e.g., manure sweeper, manure spreader, compost pile, manure pit and lagoon) used in livestock production.

F4CE268FCA794EA79D25BD2535D3E5BB.description: Describe the components of a water supply system including pressure pump, tanks with controls, filtration system and distribution.

310495BE025C4F4BB44587F6353E7C21.description: Demonstrate the operation of feed milling and processing equipment.

1BFCF3C6A83140D6B94C10EDC0337D59.description: Investigate the components and operation of feeding equipment (e.g., silos, augers, feed carts, feed rollers, mechanized conveyors, liquid feed systems and hay feeders).

248C9412A7394FFD93BC277B42ADEB9B.description: Compare the common types of feeding systems.

A6FCEE8FDCD549AEA09776B58F70643F.description: Demonstrate the ability to read and interpret controls, gauges and indicators commonly found on feed, water and waste equipment.

BCE9CFA7EA8F4A7D98B34328A8279C80.description: Explore the equipment used for feed, water and waste in livestock production.

F9AF590C7A2E4C36BE565D9E209B9E59.description: Livestock Feed, Water and Waste Equipment (Optional)

6A6CC435AD5E48FF972ED50D8E79AC3E.description: Investigate the proper mixture of prepared food for nutritional value for a specific purpose (e.g., maintenance, growing and fattening).

CDB45D1D43BB4C1C899E5B366811EAD3.description: Examine the advantages and disadvantages of commercially prepared feeds.

943A2C526A684F62B0AAC3B1FAEF9EAD.description: Discuss why a salt block is used in livestock nutrition

BFC80CACF2A647F2815A70A80FEE02E9.description: Explain how feed concentrates, supplements and creep feeding can be used to meet an animal’s unique needs.

17F7ACBE9ED74551A00A7BEA4901F167.description: Describe the water requirements of livestock, including factors that may affect these requirements (e.g., animal size, growth stage, temperature and humidity).

677A1B87926241B0807E72C7E227BE23.description: Explore the importance of calculating dry matter and using a scale to feed animals a specific weight of feed.

38E7FFE860E341C7B9EE5373D5841ED1.description: Identify the basic nutritional requirements of various livestock according to breed, age, gender, time of year, reproductive cycle and physical condition.

EBAFEDA1657D44E59A1EF04DCDCE188F.description: Define feed terminology such as total digestible nutrients, protein content, energy, trace minerals, crude protein, crude fat and feed supplements.

3C6C081D4B014F20A45A7FF75859FE5B.description: Explain the importance of traceability of livestock (e.g., source of transmissible contamination like E. Coli and proving organic status of meat).

3C245F6D7FA242F0B71D8EDBEFAE3B6C.description: Research the use of Saskatchewan Premises Identification (PID).

29D7B219163B466CB0B9221B0789867D.description: Explore codes of practice (e.g., Code of Practice for the Care and Handling of Beef Cattle by National Farm Animal Care Council [NFACC]) in the handling of specific livestock.

087A7A08A4084164A0AACACD16B162F5.description: Discuss the role of the Animal Protection Service of Saskatchewan (APSS)

BD88BCB950B2437D9130ADB3D04CBB78.description: Examine moral issues of the use of tools that cause pain (e.g., electric cattle prods, whips and electric fences) in livestock handling.

7B7281C57843434692DF51683276DA69.description: Research regulations governing enclosure size for specific types of livestock.

8315C679CCE549E4AE6F6D81B3590A93.description: Explore the laws governing improper treatment of animals.

2495B078D020415FB5579C61E13DCADE.description: Describe acceptable and unacceptable aspects of livestock management, such as principles of punishment and reward and physical and psychological abuse.

257A9833F4764A67854F4B3CC131F34C.description: Explore the regulations governing handling and treatment of livestock.

937ED2D6513C4266A7B550DA7D22CC64.description: Investigate how technology (e.g., drones) can be used to manage livestock.

4D79D589AEC841A19614CE0217600DEB.description: Explain how to use animals (e.g., horses and dogs) and vehicles (e.g., plane, helicopter, ATV and trucks) to move livestock.

485B94C6DB924DD18EF3F73719069A9C.description: Describe how to transport a sick animal.

B7B57B38D7D34ED394B3F926B89967B5.description: Discuss the characteristics of animals that are not fit for transport.

46E386D743EF4FE2B3D73B20D129725C.description: Compare different types of trailers (e.g., straight haul, angle haul and open stall) and their purpose.

47C768BA29724D53AA9E6CE0CB830A30.description: Explain how to recognize and use flight zones when handling livestock.

356CAFC98CC94D17A2DF2BF723803648.description: Demonstrate safe preparation, loading and unloading procedures.

B8CFA78140FA46A189759F90BDF39E5B.description: Explore the balance points of a chosen species of livestock.

0669DC3F89CC49D8A4B0134CF077F62B.description: Explain how to appropriately manage unwelcome behaviours (e.g., halter pulling, biting, kicking and striking).

246F46A86D5C4AC1841D16F7D84BACEE.description: Describe an animal’s expected behaviour in various situations (e.g., being led, tying, grooming, bathing, clipping, crutching and mother-baby interactions).

95F33990D08D43C28FFB9B7072C7B00E.description: Catch, halter and lead an animal safely.

9DAC2CCE11C9417FB674A5F003DD226A.description: Discuss methods of catching a difficult animal.

D3C4D54AC3DD4FEA94A7F523FD031E64.description: Explore the use of basic restraints (e.g., halter, stocks, cage and pharmaceuticals).

8C130CD2CA324A558D291EC117C5DE2D.description: Explore organizations (e.g., 4-H clubs) that teach proper handling of livestock.

9359A9BADB0946DDA25728E523685E94.description: Investigate safe methods of restraining, moving and transporting livestock.

1D4FCB8F4D894A109693796B7587628C.description: Basic Handling – Restraint, Movement and Transportation (Core)

41468199298A4FCF88C4117A1B94D1E1.description: Discuss the finances of a livestock operation including equipment and human resources, types of products (e.g., meat, eggs, wool, honey and dairy), bedding requirements (e.g., straw bales), outsourcing stages (e.g., feedlot connection), accessibility to markets, cost of input and expected revenue

DFDE1AE697504694BD7FA5945689672B.description: Examine aspects of livestock nutrition programs including sources of feed, prepared rations, feed storage, method of feeding, grazing methods and sources of water.

55B0B186898148E1AFD3CEB3725E62C3.description: Explore the biosecurity and food safety requirements (e.g., ProAction, VBP+ and Start Clean Stay Clean) for livestock production.

EB23ADA86F40438E96DC3C9B075C737A.description: Investigate livestock management practices (e.g., percentage as meat processing, pure-bred breeding stock development, crossbreeding, show and aging livestock and introduction of new animals to the herd or operation) including the ability to handle waste (e.g., manure and carcasses) and herd protection measures (e.g., herd dogs and donkeys).

F7E084CDA0A443539EF9C0925735DF5A.description: Explain the rationale for choosing a type of ranching, size of operation and breed of livestock for a given farm location.

DFD9F96456AC4E96AF7D750DD1042110.description: Explore the required structures (e.g., buildings, fences and corrals) and land (e.g., land features including soil types and use of that land) of a livestock operation.

E139FD401A61435C82FDC3F9673A8700.description: Describe the annual cycle (i.e., processes followed in a sequence over the course of a year like breeding and culling) and production cycle (e.g., postpartum, conception, mid gestation and late gestation) in livestock production.

BD4FF4FDFB874F338F2899FDEED7EE97.description: Examine the structure and organization of farm and land management plans for livestock production.

9C7A26485EFE45AB9FCE8F856C12D047.description: Apply basic repair and maintenance skills to buildings, livestock facilities, vegetation and roads.

8BCDC6A3FC714957B4EDA1D025269F17.description: Analyze the factors affecting pasture quality, including: biotic (e.g., parasites, disease and predators); environmental conditions; geographic location and slope of the land; grazing management; soil (e.g., structure, texture and pH); water access and quality; and, type of grass and/or legume.

15656361E9DB47A19345C1EBD04C9792.description: Explore the regulations and relevant calculations (e.g., animal unit month [AUM]) for determining suitable pasture size for a particular type and quantity of livestock.

6CDA1632795D4A989373AA3B46248B31.description: Identify the facility requirements and regulations for different holding areas to separate animals for various reasons (e.g., breeding, egg laying, incubators, injured or ill animal, maternity pen and weaning).

40B169ADA7064AFDADF356AB906C5284.description: Explore the governing regulations and maintenance of livestock production facilities.

09226F14DD7B4183874D5C07E9ACC9AE.description: Explain the role of the four sacred medicines (i.e., tobacco, sage, sweetgrass and cedar) in Indigenous culture.

C86FD7B47FB1409D9B2F3F3978FFA3BF.description: Discuss traditional and current Indigenous perspectives on connections to the land and agriculture with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

BDD4DC4A86A94FAD8D224B1A833EEFFF.description: Describe traditional Indigenous agricultural practices (e.g., companion planting, composting and rain gardening) that are used today to improve agricultural sustainability.

D9FA191D37AC4252B23C321E06AD634C.description: Discuss the importance of agricultural stewardship.

E30DD294C0D2422FA982EA2A7867E73E.description: Identify plants that were domesticated by First Nations peoples as a crop for a specific purpose (e.g., wild rice, corn, potatoes and tomatoes).

B4B819C2B9284720A8DCB9E10D21EFE4.description: Analyze how working with horses can benefit the rediscovery of the First Nations traditional role of horses.

8970059B187E4523A0C7E80AA40ED997.description: Explore Indigenous contributions to agriculture production.

1783581534B6405598AC8E0E9276C9CC.description: Research sources of support (e.g., websites, telehealth and community centers) for producers experiencing poor psychological health including trauma.

2EF8F29ED83D469DBC192A06FDA46FC9.description: Explore practical strategies when poor psychological health prevents an individual from accomplishing farm tasks.

FFE4CC446C614A2698DF88D7FF3C33DF.description: Discuss the benefits of monitoring and maintaining positive psychological health.

3A2533E48C9F4CF3BFE10067701F55BB.description: Describe unavoidable stresses (e.g., harvest time, calving season, weather events and relationship challenges) in agriculture production.

537F00F87207493F80B1C8D5ED62278C.description: Research how personal financial stress may impact productivity.

14693C8C287144CCBCC10E69FDBB52CC.description: Explore the prevalence of mental illness in agricultural producers in Canada

2A9C429D546B41E8BD0F648B387B1D0D.description: Describe how life/work balance can impact personal wellness.

99757D9A99F24672835098ABEC55B536.description: Investigate personal psychological health and safety in the workplace.

2C39F670E826440C98BA304037F23136.description: Practise the methods used to remove and dispose of chemical residue (e.g., fertilizer and pesticide spray) from application equipment.

FEFDA3D7FFC24C5996D07CCC963C03C3.description: Explore the environmental impacts of unsafe chemical waste disposal, and how that impacts Indigenous communities (e.g., water, animals and traditional medicinal plants).

696B7CA7300145CDAC0EEFA88F2A28E0.description: Investigate the responsibilities and correct environmental handling, cleanup and waste disposal of cleaners, containers, coolants, filters, fuel and lubricants (e.g., grease and oil) including organizations that specialize in their cleanup

B573C0E9ED1344A5B37A52BD12681251.description: Investigate regulations and responsibilities to safely dispose of leftover chemical and chemical containers.

38F79ACE04074D44A943239DD3675E73.description: Discuss first-aid procedures for exposure to agricultural chemicals (e.g., fertilizer, pesticide, fuel and anhydrous ammonia).

1F61CD6608A74E449DE1576FAC02F084.description: Develop procedures for handling mishaps such as chemical spills.

3637D7DBA5084C1E9D2671F5A223242B.description: Practise the safe storage of chemical products.

47BD12B779EA4550A80007DEF9E2FF2B.description: Demonstrate safe handling of chemical products using approved safety gear.

B1FF4FE48B4C480B98B8AB6EEF4A4854.description: Explain the uses of agricultural chemicals that would require a Saskatchewan Pesticide Applicator Licence.

04473ED5DB1748EB9CC00D9082189807.description: Explore training and certification opportunities (e.g., WHMIS and pesticide applicator licence) on the safe use of agricultural chemicals.

94A724D51EB9426081E84D2AC2D09D7D.description: Investigate record keeping strategies for maintaining SDS information.

157BA670B5F94479BEB1A1CF240A133A.description: Describe the potential heath risks of exposure to chemicals.

8BA1A98FAFCB42469D273310C7DF658A.description: Identify the types of hazardous materials that an agricultural operation might create.

268DB5014D3347E49EC1333BEABEB065.description: Discuss the purpose and intended use of the mandatory information on a pesticide label as regulated by Health Canada.

CED361EC625F483A84BAB9D8DD66AD61.description: Demonstrate the different hazards, identifiers and uses of consumer products, control products, and pesticides.

B2942B05026440F382B6EEFDE599F6C3.description: Describe the four parts of Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) (i.e., labels with warning symbols, hazard identification and product classification, Safety Data Sheets (SDS), worker education and worksite specific training).

99462085549D408CBF682CFF0C328A05.description: Identify important information categories from product labels, Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) and manufacturer’s chemical information packages such as compatibility, storage requirements, application method, preharvest intervals and withdrawal periods.

34D0ECDA4A3D4FCEA52A0526047F9425.description: Demonstrate the importance of, and methods used for, maintenance of a clean and safe workplace.

E8BA5FDFFBC9412B8DD8ED627DD04E23.description: Apply proper handling of hazardous materials to prevent injury in the workplace.

C642D24FDD254063B0D75F676AFB26B5.description: Describe potential business costs of safety or injury incidents (e.g., equipment damage, property damage, down time, insurance premiums, direct healthcare costs, client reputation and pain/suffering).

207EEA45EB3948D5A2F40D6A201BCA2A.description: Describe the financial penalties for failure to comply with the Occupational Health and Safety Regulations.

6AC91DEA644E4168BF937C0A83F78084.description: Describe the use of Hazard Identification, Risk Assessment and the Hierarchy of Controls for Risk Mitigation in Agricultural Production.

07E055C3BDCF46A59C2C425E118657FF.description: Identify the benefits to employers and employees of the Saskatchewan Workers Compensation Act and the Meredith Principles.

0DF1CDC2CD994565AC33B7E843A17C99.description: Describe when coverage from the Saskatchewan Workers’ Compensation Board (WCB) is optional and when it is mandatory.

D4BA62D44B164EFA83061B0F7485068E.description: Develop an emergency farm safety plan that includes types of anticipated emergencies and covers communication requirements (e.g., radio, mobile phone, satellite phone), training requirements, directions to location, required equipment and anticipated response times of outside aid.

EB0E1EAF5A4B42E7A6908888543A56F0.description: Identify the manufacturer’s requirements for the maintenance and storage of personal protective equipment.

D189B18D930B4289A5C66FC87220A3D8.description: Identify the manufacturer’s recommended uses and limitations for common classifications of personal protective equipment including respiratory, hearing, hand, eye and foot protection.

25A3D499D9EE410CB72A5B8EAE0EC849.description: Describe the benefits of agricultural workers obtaining emergency training including First Aid and fire extinguisher use.

3B52254A08C74EFBB708774470C69EBB.description: Identify safe and unsafe practices in using typical agricultural tools (e.g., hand tools, power tools, lifts and winches).

EFE5880AB2DA496797FE8B457E4497A2.description: Identify the types of and reasons why manufacturers include protective devices (guards) on agricultural equipment.

02A2BEF5B0294843819E7B8DE2F2C072.description: Analyze principles and techniques for injury prevention to ensure safety in agriculture production.
